title: How did the Ottoman Empire, despite being so weak, manage to defeat the British at the Siege of Kut? - Quora

response.answer_text: The “weakness” of the Ottomans — and yes, they had been the “sick man of Europe” since Czar Nicholas I called them (roughly) that in 1853 — has nothing to do with their performance in any individual battle/campaign. Overall during WWI the Turks performed poorly on offense — with Sarikamis in December, 1914, being a particular disaster, but also the Turk’s first attempt to seize the Suez Canal — but they did well when defending their own territory, as the Allies would learn first at Gallipoli and soon after at Kut. The through line between Gallipoli and Kut is that the Entente, and particularly the British, badly underestimated not just the ability, but the determination, of Turkish troops, with tragic consequences in both venues. The siege of Kut arose because Townshend advanced too far and too fast, stretching his supply lines to the breaking point and making reinforcements impossible. Then, after being turned back at the Battle of Ctesiphon, he staged a hasty (but not hasty enough) retreat. Under the circumstances, his decision to stop and defend at Kut al Amara remains debatable. On the one hand it was a defensible position and his army was exhausted; on the other, trapped by the Tigris on three sides, it was an easy position for the Turks to besiege. In retrospect — and hindsight is 20:20 — Townshend’s greatest mistake was not evacuating the city before occupying it, meaning that the roughly 6,000 residents of Kut not only had to be fed, along with his troops, but would also suffer the effects of the siege, a true tragedy of the innocent. I frequently take the stance that the worst led troops in WWI were the British — mind you, the Austrians had the worst army, but it wasn’t just because of their leadership — and at Kut this really shows. Townshend was foolish overextending his supply lines and was at best mistaken digging in at Kut, but his decisions were then compounded by a slow response from the British War Cabinet. It took them over a month to send troops to break the siege, and then, when the initial efforts failed, almost another two months to try again. In the meantime the Turks, with far shorter supply lines, were pouring almost 30,000 troops into defending the siege. As on many other occasions during the war, British leadership dithered and underestimated their opponent. The arrogance of Empire I guess. Per Wikipedia: Historian Christopher Catherwood has called the siege of Kut "the worst defeat of the Allies in World War I," which is nonsense compared to disasters like The Somme or Third Ypres (Passchendaele), but Kut was perhaps the most unnecessary debacle of the war.
